title: Built-up Index Handbook
text:
1 Welcome
Welcome to the Built-up Index Handbook!
This handbook introduces existing built-up indices, explains their principles, and provides code examples for urban studies using remote sensing.
👉 What you’ll find here: - 📖 Explanations of classic built-up indices like NDBI, UI, IBI
- 🛰️ Practical code examples in Google Earth Engine & Python
- ✅ Validation methods like TOC and Simple Random Sampling
Stay tuned – we’ll also introduce VBI after our paper is published! 🚀

title: 2  Why Built-up Indices Matter
text:
Urbanization is one of the biggest global changes of our time.
To study urban heat islands, flooding, and land-use change, researchers need to accurately map built-up areas.
Built-up indices are formulas that combine different satellite bands to highlight urban surfaces – like NDVI for vegetation, but for cities.

title: 3  NDBI – Normalized Difference Built-up Index
text:
3.1 📐 Formula
The Normalized Difference Built-up Index (NDBI), proposed by Zha et al. (2003), is the most widely used index for detecting built-up areas.
\[
NDBI = \frac{SWIR - NIR}{SWIR + NIR}
\]
crumbs: 3  NDBI – Normalized Difference Built-up Index

title: 3  NDBI – Normalized Difference Built-up Index
text:
SWIR (Short-Wave Infrared) reflects strongly from urban materials (concrete, asphalt).
NIR (Near-Infrared) reflects from vegetation.
